Description: Body sherd of Laconian black-figured pottery kylix; dull white slip; interior: below junction of rim and body, three painted black bands above part of an incised palmette with petals alternating black and added red; exterior: in handle zone, narrow black band above part of handle palmette with red; below, traces of two narrow bands.
Curator's comments: This sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.526.a, 1888,0601.526.b and 1888,0601.526.e. The fragments of the B7.4 cup show a wing and snakes, a combination that makes possible the suggestion that the subject was Typhon, although the work is too fragmentary to allow certain identification. There are some obscure points as well: wings are not a common feature for a sea-daemon. From the little that is left of B7.4, however, a reconstruction is almost impossible, so the question of form and identity must be left open. See Pipili, M., Laconian Iconography of the Sixth Century BC. Oxford 1987, 69. For a wholly preserved example of a "Typhon" see Pipili 1987, 70, fig. 102 (Cerveteri 67658).
